page.title: 08HAZEL GROVE.
page.content: The area around Moorfield School has changed greatly in the last thirty years. Where there are now rows of houses, there were open fields. The shops were small independent stores which provided a delivery service to customers. The milkman travelled by horse and cart. Mirlees Blackstone Engineering was the main employer in the area. One zebra crossing was sufficient for pedestrians using the A6. The train service into Manchester had been withdrawn soon after the war. Other schools were Norbury C. of E. and Hazel Grove Junior School. The High School on Jacksons Lane was in existence as a secondary school. As farming land was sold, new housing estates sprang up and the Junior and Infant schools, and St.Peter's Catholic school were built to cater for the growing school population.
